Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door of our house unless someone knocks on the door, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time and when I have the garage doors open, it feels like I'm more tuned into the neighborhood. On holidays it is pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some of the neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same at other holidays like Mother's day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.
My neighborhood is in the smack middle of the high desert, where there is dirt, dirt and more dirt. Unless someone has actually experienced living here, they probably donâ€™t really understand the feeling of always seeing brown , and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spread out far and wide. Now it is pretty much the same way by there are a lot of new additions. Honestly this place looks more and more like a city everyday, but supposed most places are changing the same way. Most of the time the people are very friendly, but just like any city you have your good parts and bad. In my neighborhood I'm surrounded by friendly old people iI guess it's a nicer neighborhood. The stores in this place are pretty much the store who have chains, like food for less and smart and final. If you want uscale you have to travel I never really see any whole foods or stores of that nature. The jobs that are most prominent in my city I would say not based on any official demographics, is construction. I think this is on account of this city is still not very developed, there is still a lot of wide open spaces to build. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not keen on going back. Speaking of construction this was the field my full time job is located in, i am a drywall and T-bar instalator. What I like about my home is the different animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not the least of which is the stark beauty of the desert itself. High desert climate and topography have created challenging ecosystems which need protecting and which are home to different types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment in order to co-exist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted very well to the wildlife. I have three children and they are all obsessed with lizards and dessert bugs, as I am writing this now they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As far as attractions goes we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can generate a different experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Pop by the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to finish out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry of Victorville.
When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm sure that my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are most likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a tad bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus that I stay on, and the people that live in my dormitory to be my community. I also consider the surrounding campus to be my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with the more conventional ideas about a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the neighborhood I stay in has houses, people, stores and parks. Let us begin by discussing the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before I begin to explore the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of house that can be found in my neighborhood. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity, the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. First, In the apartments, there are usually between 2-4 people in any given room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can house about 2 floors, so on average, there are 20 or so people living in each building. Second, are the actual houses that are available for anyone with an affiliation to the school to rent. Typically these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them. However, there are only a handful of these types of houses spread throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms which house 100's of students. In these, you have two people sharing a room with some exception, and it is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered we are ready to move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity and this is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages that live in my neighborhood. Most of the professional staff live in the houses that are placed in the neighborhood, whereas the newer students stay in the dormitory style housing and the older students stay in the apartment-style housing. The people in this neighborhood can't be done justice by simply talking about them, so it would be best to simply move on to the stores and parks in my neighborhood. Since my school really is it's own self-contained neighborhood, it has a plethora of stores and a single park. The stores are a mix of dining options that would be found in any other neighborhood, and the schools own unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. As such, anything that is needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries! Additionally, the park in my neighborhood is a playground for all the diverse people in my neighborhood, it is kept clean and free of crime by all the members of my neighborhood!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I live in a small town in Michigan, far from big cities. Here, farms meet small towns that welcome visitors. We do not have large stores or many restaurants. We must drive to get most places. Still, I live in one of the most beautiful areas in our country. Water is all around us. The big Lake Michigan is on one side, and Lake Charlevoix is on the other. You can find places to put your feet in the water everywhere.

My town shows what small-town life is like. Houses stand far apart from each other. Each house looks different and many are old. Some owners fix their old houses while others leave them as they are. Most houses have rooms below ground that you can see from the street. Many homes have metal on their walls. The houses come in many colors. Most have yards where children play. Some people grow plants for food or keep animals behind walls.

These homes show how normal people live. People work hard and raise families here. Children play in the streets. People walk their dogs or ride bikes. Everyone knows their neighbors. We can tell who belongs here. People cook food outside and wave to others who walk by.

The yards look nice. No dead leaves stay on the ground long. The grass is green and cut short. Plants and trees are kept neat. When people drive through, they might think this is a good place for families. It is quiet and safe. It may look simple, but it gives people what they want - a good place to come home to.

Near us, we have important buildings like the police station and health office. We have a place to take things to be made new again. There are fields where people play games, and you can hear someone telling who is winning. Small planes fly from our airport nearby. We can walk to get ice cream or go to the center of town. My children can ride their bikes to the park. This is a very good place to live.

I live in a planned community in the outer part of a city. All the houses look very much alike. A group called the homeowner's association makes sure everything stays clean and orderly.

When you enter our neighborhood, you see many similar houses. Each has a small green yard in front with rocks and small trees. Every house has room for two cars. The streets are very smooth and well-kept. Most houses are one floor high, but some have two floors.

We do not have separate mail boxes for each house. Instead, we share a group of mail boxes at the end of the street. Each family has a key to get their mail. There are also special boxes for bigger packages.

Our neighborhood is special because it sits where the city meets the countryside. This gives us lots of space. We have several swimming pools that everyone can use. There are also paths where people can walk or run. You do not need to go to a park to exercise here.

Most people who live here are older and no longer work. Some younger working people live here too. Everyone knows each other and helps keep the area safe.

The city is big enough to have everything we need. We have one shopping center. It takes about fifteen minutes by car to reach most stores. We have many different kinds of stores, from expensive food markets to low-cost shops.

This is a good place to live. It is safe and clean. While stores are not very close, we can drive to any store we want. The swimming pools and walking paths make it even better.

I first learned about my home while listening to a radio show about missing people. This surprised me. Most homes in this area cost more than one thousand dollars each month to live in. I had never heard this story before, and neither had my friends. 

Life here can be hard. Some of my friends cry at night because things cost so much money. We have learned to live with less. We buy things from places that sell used goods. These places have a special smell - like old books and clothes stored away for a long time. As you get older, you notice these smells less.

In my area, there are three stores that sell used items within walking distance. You can visit two stores that help people in need, a library, a store with old books, and a shop with interesting old things. The city center is busy with cars and people each morning, but these stores are always quiet. They are good places to spend time.

The city is growing bigger. More cars and people come here every year. A big internet shopping company has its main office here. This reminds me of New York City. Everyone focuses on their own life, and no one asks too many questions. You can be by yourself, and people will let you be. It is different from the South, where people often want to know about your life.

I live with good neighbors. The person next door plays piano, and two people upstairs like to sing. We are like friends more than strangers. We help each other, share food, and come together for happy and sad times. We bring each other's mail and keep our shared spaces clean.

Even though I live in a big city that can feel cold and unfriendly, my neighbors make it feel like home. They help me feel that I made a good choice to live here.

I live in a small town in the middle of America, near a big city. I live on the east side of town, where many people do not have much money. The houses here cost less than in other parts of town, and most people rent their homes. Still, it is a nice place. My neighbors are friendly and say hello when they see me.

While crime is a little higher here than in other parts of town, it is still mostly safe. There have been some bad events near my home in the past ten years, including some shootings. Our neighbors lost their son in a shooting last year. My family has been lucky, though we sometimes lose small things from our front steps if we forget to bring them inside.

Like many places in America, our town has problems with dangerous drugs. Many people have died from these drugs. However, there are places in town that help people who want to stop using drugs. There are also classes to teach people how to help someone who has taken too many drugs.

There are many good things about our town. My son's school is very good. The teachers and workers there are kind. Even though my son has special needs, other children are nice to him, and he loves his school. Parents and teachers work together to make the school better. Because many families in town do not have much money, all children get free food at school. No one is treated badly because they cannot pay for things.

The town leaders have made the streets and parks look better. However, most of these improvements are in the middle of town and on the west side, where the stores are. The east side, where I live, often gets left out. This makes people in my area unhappy.

Still, I like living here. People are friendly, the schools are good, and there are enough stores to buy what we need. Our house is not worth much money, but it is comfortable. We have lived here for more than 16 years, and we want to stay here.

I live in a special part of the city called Hilltop. My home is in a tall building near an old theater. Down the street, there is a place where people play games and meet friends. In summer, many people wait in line to enter this place.

Near my home is a city park. The park has tall steps made of concrete around it. In winter, people who have no homes put their tents on these steps and nearby walkways. The rain makes winter hard for them, but staying close to the city center helps them stay warmer. They can also walk to a place where they can wash.

What makes this area special is not just the old buildings or the way the streets go down toward the water. It is the people who live here. Years ago, this area was known as a dangerous place. Government workers tried to make it safer. People still tell stories about those times.

Today, people work hard to make this area better. Some say white people should not walk here at night, but I think this idea comes from old fears. Maybe it is because my skin is not fully white, or maybe because the people here know me, but I feel safe. 

The people here are kind. Once, when I needed to charge my phone during rain, the washing place stayed open late to help me. When I had nowhere to go and sat on the street, someone gave me money and told me I was worth something.

This place shows that old ideas about race and fear can change. Even though some think this area is rough, to me it is home. No matter where I go, Hilltop will always be special to me.

I came to live in this area when I was ready to start my last year of middle school. At first, it was not easy to find friends, but I became close with two boys who lived near my house. They have moved away now, but I still remember our time together. Most of the same people who lived here when I came still live here today.

My area looks like many other American living areas outside big cities. Most houses have two floors. When the weather is warm, I can hear children playing outside, especially on weekends. Most days are quiet here. I have never had trouble with anyone who lives nearby. People leave you alone unless you need help. When I get things sent to my house, no one takes them. I feel safe with my neighbors.

There is a small park very close to my house. I have played many games there like basketball and football with other young people. Once, I got hurt playing football there, but most of my memories are good ones. Now, I take my young cousin's children to play there. They love the swings and slides. They get very happy when we talk about going to the park. When I go there now, I think about all the good times I had there when I was younger.

Many different kinds of people live here. You can find food from many countries nearby. There are eating places that serve Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian food within a short drive. Many people now use their phones to have food brought to their homes. There are also many quick-food places and pizza shops.

We have all the stores we need. There are places to clean clothes, two drug stores, and a big food store. There is even a store that sells Indian food and cooking things.

I really like living in this area. When I read about problems other people have with their neighbors, I feel very lucky to live here.

I live near my college, which makes me happy. My area has many apartment buildings and some places to eat and drink. These places do not cost too much money. One drinking place got a new name and costs more now, but it is still fine to visit.

The people who live here are nice. Many are students or people who do not have much money, as the homes are not expensive. There are many children because a school is close by. I do not know the people who live next to me, and that is fine. They smoke a lot, so the building owners put something in the hall to make the air smell better. My friend and I think this is funny.

Most buildings here are old, but some are fixed up inside. There are new apartments down the street, but they were not built well. They cost too much money because they are near the school.

There is a very cheap eating place near me. They use paper plates and heat most food in a small oven. Next to it is a place to buy gas. The city made the street better last summer. Now there is a good walking path and green grass on both sides.

Many trees grow around my building. Some were cut down, but many still stand. Behind my home are more trees and more apartments. I live on one street, but the street behind mine is not as nice. The walking paths there are broken, and the buildings look old. The trees there help hide how the buildings look. Bad things sometimes happen in that area, and also across from where I live.

Still, I like my home. I can pay for it, and everything I need is close. I can walk to school, and I can take a bus to buy food or go to the center of town.

I live in a special group of houses. Each house has two homes inside it. The houses are placed apart from each other on a road that ends in a circle. All the houses are yellow with white front areas and green metal tops.

Most people here are friends. In the evening, we often meet and talk while children play with their toys or draw on the ground. Sometimes they fly kites. It feels like an old-time way of life, away from computers. We have fields and trees all around us, with blue sky and white clouds above.

The only bad thing is the strong storms we get. Last night, we heard warning sounds for a dangerous wind storm. I had to hide in my bathroom with my small dog and some important things. My big dog stayed in the living room, making noise because he was afraid. Outside, ice fell from the sky. After the storm, the road was hot and giving off steam. The weather changed quickly, going from very hot to cooler. When the sun came out while it was still raining, two colorful lines appeared in the sky. I took pictures to show my friends.

The street was quiet for a while until people came home. Then life went back to normal, with mothers and children outside while food was cooking. I moved here from the north, and I like how people talk here in the south. My home has two rooms and two bathrooms, like the others. But inside, the homes are different. Some are very small.

I enjoy walking in the big field behind my house. There is a small lake there, but we cannot swim in it. I see deer sometimes, and in the morning, I hear big frogs making noise. I live forty minutes from a big city. Every morning, I hear farm birds making noise, and sometimes a donkey makes sounds in the evening. It feels like a small village. I am very happy I found this special place to live.

I have lived in my neighborhood for ten years, and I want to share my story. When I first moved here, I was very sad. We moved from Riverdale to Stockbridge because my parents wanted a better life for me and my little sister. They chose this area for its good schools and nice houses.

Over time, I made new friends at school. I did not know many neighbors, except for Mr. Glen and Dennis, who live next door. They became like family to us. I remember going to Mr. Glen's wedding with my family. It was a very happy day. At the wedding, I caught the small white band that Ms. Veda threw from her leg. I danced with their daughter Marsharii, but I have not seen her since then.

Our neighborhood is like a maze, but now I use a GPS to find my way around. I often spent time with my friends Kason and Curtis playing video games. I also like to go to the park. Being in nature makes me feel calm and peaceful. I practice my balance there with sticks I bought from the store, and sometimes I bring my wooden practice sword.

The park has places to play basketball and tennis. I have not played these sports lately, but it is good to know they are there. When I was younger, my father taught me and my best friend how to play tennis with Mr. Graves. They made us work hard, but we had fun.

I have many good memories in this neighborhood. These are the ones that mean the most to me, and I believe even better things will happen in the future.

I live in a small town called Johnston in South Carolina. Our town is special because we grow many peaches. In fact, we call ourselves the Peach Capital of the World, and this is written on our welcome sign.

Most of our land is used for growing peaches or raising cows. Houses outside the town center are far apart. These homes usually have two floors with metal or gray tops to help stay cool in the hot summer. Many houses sit far from the road, with fields in front for animals or growing food.

In the middle of town, we have one traffic light where four roads meet. All our stores are here. We have three places to eat: a Chinese family restaurant called Hong Kong, a Mexican place called Fiesta, and a burger place called Gary's. We also have a small drug store famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola, and one grocery store called IGA. Most people drive to a bigger store called Walmart in another town for their main shopping.

The busiest store is Dollar General, which sells many everyday things. We have a furniture store run by a nice woman who will send workers to bring furniture to your home. Next door is a place where people can take their pets for cleaning and care.

We have one doctor's office and one animal doctor's office outside the town center. There is one school for young children, but older students must go to school in another town. We do not have a park yet, but the town is building one that will be quite big.

There are no movie theaters, places to bowl, or many restaurants. Still, Johnston is a nice place to live, even though it is so small you might miss it if you drive through too fast!

I live in a small town in Tennessee. My home is on a street that connects two main roads. Cars often pass by, but our area is mostly quiet. Many people have lived here for a long time, and we know most of them.

People here spend time working in their yards and doing daily tasks. In winter, children slide down a hill on our side street. Our house sits at the front of the street, so we see everyone who comes and goes. We know which cars belong here, and we notice when we see new ones.

Some people walk for exercise or with their dogs. Children ride bikes in the street. My family stays home a lot because we work there. There are four of us - me, my wife, and two daughters who are eleven and fourteen years old.

We like to play outside, even when it rains. Sometimes we cook food on our back deck. The smell of cooking food is nice. From spring to fall, someone is always cutting grass. You can hear lawn machines almost every day.

We have many trees in our area because it was once a forest. The trees give us shade, but they drop many leaves in fall. We must gather the leaves and burn them each year. I like how burning leaves smell. It tells us fall is here. Recently, winters have been warm, so it feels like fall stays longer.

Our garage is behind our house, so we rarely use the front door. When I work on my truck in the garage, I can see and hear what happens in our area. During holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas, it gets very quiet here. Sometimes families have visitors, and many cars park on our street.

I am happy living here. It would be perfect if fewer cars drove through our street.

I live in the high desert. There is mostly brown dirt everywhere you look. People who have not lived here may not understand what it is like to see brown all the time. When you see green grass, you know someone is paying a lot of money to keep it that way.

I moved here in the 1990s when houses were far apart. It is still like that today, but there are more new houses now. Our area is growing like a city, which is happening in many places. Most people here are friendly. Like all cities, there are good and bad areas. I live near many kind older people in a nice part of town.

The stores here are mostly big chain stores. We do not have fancy stores nearby. You must drive far to find them. Many people here work in building houses and buildings. This is because our city still has lots of empty space to build on. This worries me because I like how things are now. I left a big city and do not want to live in one again. I work in building too, putting up walls in new buildings.

What I like most are the desert animals. People come here to see the desert's simple beauty. The high desert has special plants and animals that need to be protected. People who live here should learn about these animals to live safely with them. My family enjoys the wildlife. My three children love catching and watching lizards and desert insects.

There are some interesting places to visit here. The San Bernardino County Fair is a fun yearly event. Near us is Wrightwood, where you can see snow and learn winter sports. The Victor Valley Museum shows interesting things about our area's past, including rocks, old animal bones, and items from Native Americans who lived here long ago.

My neighborhood is different from what most people might describe. I live on a college campus, and my main community is the people in my dormitory building. The larger campus area is also part of what I think of as my neighborhood.

Even though this is not a usual neighborhood, it has many of the same things you would find in any other area. There are places to live, shops, and a park.

Let me tell you about the different places where people live here. We have three kinds of buildings. First, there are apartment buildings where small groups of students live together. Each apartment usually has two to four people, and there are several apartments in each building. Second, there are regular houses that school workers and former students can rent. These houses are fewer in number. Third, there are the big dormitory buildings where hundreds of students live. In these buildings, two students usually share one room.

The people who live here come from many different places and cultures. The school workers usually live in the houses. New students live in the dormitory buildings, while older students often choose to live in the apartments.

Our neighborhood has many stores where we can buy what we need. We have places to eat, shops that sell school clothes, and stores where we can buy food. There is also a nice park where people can spend time outside. Everyone helps keep the park clean and safe.

Everything we need is right here in our campus neighborhood. It is like a small town where people from different backgrounds live and work together.

I live in a place with few walking paths. My house is at the top of a very steep hill. Many people who exercise like to run up this hill. Since there are no walking paths, people must walk on the road. The road has many holes and can be dangerous to drive on.

The power and telephone lines look old and broken. It rains a lot here, and falling tree parts often break these lines. When workers fix them, the repairs do not look nice.

There are many tall green trees here. But people do not like these trees because they block the view of the water. That is why houses are built high on the hill. They have big windows on their upper floors to see the water. When the sun goes down, the water looks beautiful and bright, and the sky turns orange. But most days are gray and wet.

Green plants grow on everything here - house tops, cars, and metal rails. Once, I left my car outside for a month. When I came back, it was covered in green growth. It took me three hours to clean it off.

Not many young people live here, even though there is a school nearby. Most people who live here are old and do not work anymore. Instead of children, people have dogs. You often see dogs in yards or running in the streets. Sometimes they even come into houses if doors are left open. This happened to me once.

Many rabbits live here too. They are big and they dig holes in people's gardens. My cats hunt these rabbits. We also have many birds - small ones, very tiny fast ones, and big hunting birds. But when big birds come, the black birds chase them away.

There are no stores near my house. But if you walk down to the water, you can eat at places that serve fresh fish. There is not much sand by the water, but you can throw rocks into it. The water is not very wide. You can see the other side most days, even when it is not clear.

Bensonhurst is a part of Brooklyn that is easy to find. You can get there using public transportation, which many people in New York City use. The area feels like a city neighborhood.

When you visit, you will see many Asian stores. In the past twenty years, many Asian people have moved to Bensonhurst. You can find Asian-owned stores on almost every street. Many of these are food stores and places to wash clothes. Local people like these stores because the food is good, prices are low, and the stores are close to their homes. Near my home, there are four Asian food stores within a short walk.

The area has people from many different places. There are people who came from other countries, and their children who were born in America. Many of the big stores in the area are owned by Asian people.

There is also a new park nearby. It has basketball courts, a big field for sports, places to play handball, and areas for children to play. In summer, children can play in water fountains. People from different backgrounds play together here.

Most people live in two-family houses. There are also some bigger buildings where people can buy homes. The area does not have many big office buildings.

The people are friendly, but it can be noisy. Cars often play loud music, and some drivers make their cars very loud. At night, you should be careful. While the area is mostly safe, some people might cause trouble. There are people who steal things left outside homes. Also, even though there are rules about cleaning up after dogs, some people do not follow them. You need to watch where you walk.

Despite these problems, Bensonhurst is still a good place to visit. Just be aware of your surroundings and careful where you step.

Portland, Oregon is a special city. Many people there like to say "Keep Portland Different." This saying appears on a building that is both a place to eat and enjoy music.

In the past, Portland was less known and less costly to live in. Many creative people made their home there. Now, more people with money are moving to Portland, especially from California. Yet, the city keeps its unusual spirit.

Portland accepts many things that other places might not. We have normal stores and businesses like other cities. We have people who work in offices and people who enjoy simple activities like yoga. But we take life less seriously here.

In my area, houses are painted in bright colors. People grow flowers and food in their front yards. During warm months, many people put boxes on the street with free things inside. These boxes often have clothes and books that anyone can take. Walking through the streets, you might find something special you never expected.

Different people enjoy Portland in different ways. Some go to special events like soccer games or do yoga with small farm animals. Others spend time at local eating and drinking places. The city welcomes all kinds of interests.

Portland has problems, too. When the gray sky and rain stay for many months, it can make people feel sad. Some people use harmful drugs. Many people do not have homes. The city tries to help those without homes, but like other places in America, it is hard to solve these problems.

In Portland, you can be different and still feel at home. That is what makes this city special to me.

The mountains stand in the north. They watch the sun rise and set each day. Even when I am too busy with work to notice them, they remain strong and unmoved. On hard days when I feel worried, the mountains catch my eye. Looking at them helps calm my mind and gives me strength to continue.

I came here for college. The mountains near the school were the first thing that caught my attention. The school itself is beautiful, with nice buildings and small lakes with trees. But the mountains are what I love most.

The town is lovely too. There are many coffee shops where students spend hours studying. A short bus ride takes you to the old part of town, where red and brown bricks cover the walls of restaurants and offices. This area feels as busy as a big city. But walk past the library, and you find yourself back in a quiet town again. These different feelings make the city special, like it wants you to explore it.

I have made many happy memories here. I remember walking with friends by the old park swings after staying up all night. I remember running to catch free movies at the nice theater downtown. But sad memories exist here too. I often sat by the small lakes at night, watching ducks and turtles while thinking about life's big questions. Sometimes I cried there at two in the morning, wondering about my place in the world.

One day, I walked past the lake, through the quiet streets with small houses. I reached a main road just as the sun was rising. The light touched the tall trees and made the sky bright. I looked up and saw I was walking north. And there they were – the mountains, touching the blue and yellow morning sky. Without words, they reminded me to stay strong.

At first, you might not see it. Behind the stores is a place where people live, though most would not think to look there. If you walk past the old, empty food store and the hotels that are mostly quiet except in summer, you will find many people living together.

On these streets, there are several apartment buildings. They stand next to each other like boxes in a row. The first building you see has had some problems, so we will not talk about it much. But the other buildings next to it are special places that few people know about.

Across the street is a small college where students come to learn. They arrive early in the morning with their coffee, walking through the metal gates while cars wait on the road. The street ends at another road where there is a park on one side and a medical center on the other. The medical center has chairs on its front porch and a fan that moves slowly in the warm air.

In the park, children play in the grass while bees fly among the flowers. Older people walk their dogs on the paths. They look unhappy when they see young people on skateboards, but they smile at the young girls talking near the play equipment.

Next to the park is a small group of stores. There is a place that serves Japanese food, a store that sells things for swimming pools, and a place where people get their fingernails painted. There is also a shop that sells cold sweet treats. Young people from the park often buy these treats and eat them while they play with their skateboards.

This neighborhood is like many others in the American South. It is a quiet place where things stay the same for a long time.

I want to tell you about where I live. The houses in my area are mostly for one family, but some are split for two families to live in them. My house has a small green space in front and a place for cars on the left side. Many houses here look like they are from an earlier time in America, when people wanted to live away from the city.

The old dream of living here is not as strong as before, but we still try to keep it alive. People seem less happy now, and they do not take care of their yards as well as before. Still, every house has cars, and children play in the streets like nothing else matters.

The school has been here for almost 100 years. It still gives young people hope and makes older people remember good times. There are not many churches now, but many young people still play basketball.

All houses look different but give the same feeling. We have a big food store run by a family from Yemen - they might be the only Arab family here. Most people living here are African American.

The streets are wide. Children play football and only stop when cars need to pass. Many families have lived here for many years. They tell stories about times when everyone knew each other.

We used to have a place that taught fighting skills, but now it is a drug store. We have a small movie house that shows old films for less money. Young people do not go there much, but older people like it.

A big road passes near our town, but you cannot get on it here. Young people wanted a way to get on the road from our town, but older people said no. They thought it would hurt our town.

They are building a new school for older students. We are trying to pick something to represent our town. I think we should choose something that shows both old and new things about our town.

I live in a big city where many different kinds of people live close to each other. There are homes near places where people work and shop. You can find many offices, stores, restaurants, and places where people go to have fun. There are many places to eat and buy things. Some stores are part of big companies that everyone knows, but there are also many small stores owned by local people. These stores are in shopping centers and along the streets near quiet living areas.

There are parks nearby where families take their children to play. Many different groups of people live in my area. We have gay people, Jewish people who follow old traditions, and people who came from Russia and nearby countries. If you go a little further, you can find areas where Chinese, Korean, and Armenian people live together in their own small communities.

Getting around the city can be hard. A ten-mile trip can take two hours when there are many cars on the road. Most people drive cars instead of walking, even though some places are close by. This means it is often hard to find a place to park your car. The city is getting bigger, with many new tall buildings where people can live. Some people who already live here worry about more people and cars coming to the city.

People live in different kinds of homes here. Some live in big buildings with many apartments. Others live in single houses or smaller buildings. In my own area, you can find all these different kinds of homes. People of all ages live here, but I do not know many of my neighbors well. When I was young, I used to play outside with the children who lived next door, but now people do not spend as much time with their neighbors.

"What do you see here?" she asked as we drove past fields of corn that went as far as the eye could see. "This is all there is!" I replied. I knew she would be surprised by how empty the land looked. She grew up where stores were close to her home. She had never seen so much open space before.

I told her about growing up in Ohio's farming area. As we talked, she began to understand my background better. If you drive on the small road, you will find a water-filled hole in the ground where stone was once removed. My neighborhood is just past it. The houses are made of red stone and special wall material. Each house has a big yard that everyone keeps very nice.

In spring, there are many flowers and trees that change with each season. Nice cars sit in every driveway, shining in the sun after being washed. Near my gray house, my friend from Korea spends much time cutting his grass. We often hear him singing while he works. Everyone likes him because he is very friendly. He was a doctor before, but now he is older and moves more slowly.

At my house, birds walk in the yard while our small dog runs after them. Behind the house, there is a small stream of water that flows to the big hole. You can hear frogs and water moving, and sometimes cows from nearby farms. Across a wooden bridge we made, there is an area full of trees, plants, and wild flowers. I spent most of my young days there. I built houses in trees and ran after animals. There were always other children to play with.

The cold times can be hard, but they are very beautiful. The green yard becomes white and empty. The trees lose their colorful flowers and become bare. When snow falls, everything looks magical overnight. My younger sister made snow shapes on the ground, and we built snow people. We often threw snow at each other and made snow houses with tree branches to hide behind. In our special place, we played and did not worry about anything. We were just children having fun.
